snippet: Some want a chimney built by German P.O.W.’s in Charleston, S.C., to be saved as a piece of history. Others want it to go the way of the Nazis.
abstract: Dan Barry This Land column notes that a chimney built in Charleston, SC, by imprisoned German soldiers during the final year of World War II has become object of disagreement in the community; city officials and preservationists want to protect the chimney, but owners of property on which it stands, who are Jewish, see it as a memorial to evil.
lead_paragraph: Some want a chimney built by German P.O.W.’s in Charleston, S.C., to be saved as a piece of history. Others want it to go the way of the Nazis.

headline.print_headline: For Some, a Relic Stings as a Shrine to Nazism
headline.main: For Some, a Relic Stings as a Shrine to Nazism
